CONTACT (phassa): The word phassa comes from the verb phusati, meaning "to touch", but contact should not be understood as a simple physical effect of an object on the physical ability [touch]. Rather, it is a mental factor through which consciousness mentally "touches" an object that has just appeared, thereby initiating a whole cognitive event.
CHARACTERISTIC: touch
FUNCTION: the collision of consciousness and object.
MANIFESTATION: the coincidence of consciousness with sensory ability.
THE IMMEDIATE CAUSE: the object field that has come into focus.
2 \nfeeling \n(vedana)

FEELING (vedana): Feeling is the mental factor that the object feels, it is the emotional tone in which the object is experienced. The Pali word Vedana does not mean emotion (which is a complex phenomenon involving a set of accompanying mental factors), it is the most elementary emotional quality of experience, which can be pleasant, painful or neutral. \n While other mental factors outlive the object only indirectly, the feeling experiences it directly and completely. In this regard, other mental factors they are compared to the cook who prepares a dish for the king and only tastes it during cooking, while the feeling is compared to the king himself, who enjoys this food as much as he wants.
CHARACTERISTIC: Sensitivity
FUNCTION: experiencing, or enjoying the desired object directly.
MANIFESTATION: savoring associated mental factors.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: contact.
3 \nPerception \n(saňňā)
PERCEPTION (saññā): His mode of action is comparable to the carpenterёs recognition of certain types of wood by means of marks placed [earlier] on each of them.
CHARACTERISTIC: distinguishing the qualities of an object.
FUNCTION: recognition of what was perceived earlier.
MANIFESTATION: interpretation of an object through previously perceived features.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: the object as it appears to perception.
4 \nVolition \n(chetanā)

WOLITION (chetanā): Chetanā - from the same root as and citta, is a mental factor that deals with the actualization of the goal, that is, with the voluntary or volitional aspect of cognition. Therefore it is translated as “will.” The comments explain that chetana organizes the associated mental factors in the process of their influence on the object. As the main student repeats your own lesson and also forces other students repeat their lessons, and the will, starting to work in relation to its object, also forces the associated mental states to perform their own tasks. Volition is the most important mental factor in the generation of kamma, since it is volition that determines ethical quality of action.
CHARACTERISTICS: state of volition.
FUNCTION: accumulate (kamma).
MANIFESTATION: coordination.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: associated conditions.
5 \nUnidirectionality \n(ekaggatā)

ONE-DIRECTIONALITY (ekaggatā): This is unification mind on the object. Although this factor reaches its expressiveness only in the jhanas, where it functions as a factor jhānas, the Abhidhamma teaches that the germ of this ability to mental unification is present in all types of consciousness, even the most rudimentary. In them it functions as the factor which fixes the mind on the object.
CHARACTERISTIC: non-wandering or non-distraction.
FUNCTION: collect, or combine, associated states.
MANIFESTATION: like peace.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: happiness
6 \nMental life-controlling ability \n(jivitindriya)

JIVITINRIYA: There are two types of control life-faculties: mental, which animates associated mental states, and physical, which animates material phenomena. But as cetasika This means only the mental life-controlling ability.
CHARACTERISTICS: maintaining associated mental states.
FUNCTION: to cause associated mental states to occur.
MANIFESTATION: establishing the presence of associated mental states.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: mental states that need to be maintained.

7 \nAttention \n(manasikara)

ATTENTION (manasikāra): this is mental the factor responsible for directing the mind towards an object, whereby the object becomes presented to the consciousness. Attention - how the ship`s rudder, which guides it to its destination, or like a charioteer who sends well-trained horses (i.e. associated states) towards their destination (object). Mental factor manasikāra must be distinguished from vitakka: at that time how manasikāra directs the accompanying mental factors to an object, Vittaka applies them to the object. Manasikāra is an obligatory cognitive factor, present in all states of consciousness; vitakka - special alised factor that is not mandatory for process of cognition.
CHARACTERISTICS: leading (sārana) of associated mental states towards an object.
FUNCTION: bind associated states to an object.
MANIFESTATION: manifests itself as a confrontation with the object.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: object.
Association with consciousness

89 or 121 
 types of consciousness 
 (chitta)

The Pali word "chitta" comes from the verb root chiti - “to know, to know.” 
 Commentators define citta in three ways: as an agent, as an instrument and as an activity. As an agent, citta is that which cognizes the object (āramman am cinteti ti cittam). 
 As an instrument, citta is that by which the accompanying mental factors cognize the object (etena chintenti ti chittam). 
 As the activity of citta itself is nothing other than as a process of cognition of an object (chintanamattam chittam). 
 The third definition, given in terms of activity, is considered the most appropriate of them; that is, citta is fundamentally the activity, or process, of cognition, or knowledge, of an object. It is not an agent or a tool, having actual existence in itself, separate from activity or cognition. Definitions in terms of agent and instrument are proposed to refute the misconception of those who believe that the permanent personality, or ego, is the agent and instrument of knowledge. Buddhist thinkers through These definitions indicate that it is not the personality that carries out the act of cognition, but citta, or consciousness. This citta is nothing more than an act of cognition, and this act is necessarily temporary, marked by emergence and disappearance. 
 While citta has the sole characteristic of knowing the object, a characteristic which remains the same in all its various manifestations, the Abhidhamma distinguishes different types of citta. These the types, also called cittas, number eighty-nine, or, if classified more closely, one hundred and twenty-one. What we usually think about as consciousness, is in fact a series of cittas - instantaneous acts of consciousness, occurring in such rapid succession that we are unable to notice the individual moments of their occurrence, belonging to different types. The Abhidhamma not only distinguishes these types of consciousness, but, more importantly, it also shows them in a certain ordered system, a single and closely intertwined whole.
CHARACTERISTIC: knowledge of the object (vijānana).
FUNCTION: to be a “forerunner” (pubbangama) mental factors, in the sense that citta predominates above them and always accompanied by them.
MANIFESTATION: the way in which it appears to the experience of the meditator is it is a continuous connectedness of processes (sandhana).
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: mental-material (nāmarupa), because consciousness cannot arise one, in the complete absence of mental factors and material phenomena.

CHETASIKAS are mental phenomena that occur in direct connection with chitta, or consciousness, and will perform more specific tasks in the general act of cognition, thereby helping the chitta. Mental factors cannot arise without citta, just as citta cannot be completely separated from mental factors. But, despite the fact that functionally these two types of realities are independent, Chitta is considered as the main one because mental factors help in the knowledge of the object depending on citta, which is the main cognitive element. \n The relationship between the Citta and the Cetasikas is comparable to the relationship between a king and his retinue. Although they say: “The king is coming,” the king does not come alone, he always comes accompanied by his assistants. Likewise, whenever citta arises, it never arises alone, and always accompanied by his retinue - a cetasik.

ETHICALLY VARIABLE FACTORS (annasamānachetasika): 

 The first two categories of mental factors are the seven universal mental factors and six that occur from time to time - united under the title annasamāna, conventionally translated here as “ethically variable.” The expression literally means "in common with others." The non-beautiful cittas are called “other” (anna) in relation to the beautiful cittas, and the beautiful cittas are called “other” in relation to the cittas that are not beautiful. The thirteen cetasikas of the first two categories are common (samāna) both for the beautiful, so for non-beautiful cittas, and accept the ethical quality transferred to the citta by other cetasikas, namely, the roots associated with it (hetu). In wholesome cittas they become wholesome, in unwholesome cittas they become unwholesome, and in kammically indefinite cittas they become kammically indefinite. For this reason they are called “common with others,” that is, ethically variable.
1 \nInitial Application \n(vitakka)

INITIAL APPLICATION (vitakka): The mental factor vitakka is also presented in the discussion of the jhānas, where it is presented as the first of the five jhānic factors. Vitakka is the application of the mind to the object. Its characteristic is the directing of the mind onto the object. Its function is to strike and thresh the object. It is manifested as the leading of the mind onto the object. Although no proximate cause is mentioned in the commentaries, the object itself can be understood as its proximate cause. Ordinarily, vitakka simply applies the mind to the object. But when this mental factor is cultivated through concentration, it becomes a jhāna factor. In this case, it is called appanā— "absorption of the mind in the object." Vitakka is also called saṅkappa— "intention"— and as such is distinguished as micchāsaṅkappa, or wrong intention, and sammāsaṅkappa, or right intention. The latter is the second factor of the Noble Eightfold Path.
CHARACTERISTIC: the directing of the mind onto the object.
FUNCTION: to strike and thresh the object.
MANIFESTATION: It is manifested as the leading of the mind onto the object.
PROXIMATE CAUSE: the object itself can be understood as its proximate cause.

2 \nSustained Application \n(vicāra)

SUSTAINED APPLICATION (vicāra): Vicāra, which is also a jhāna factor, has the characteristic of continued pressure on the object in the sense of examining it. While they often occur together, initial application is the first impact of the mind in the sense of grossness and the beginning stage, similar to the striking of a bell. Sustained application is the act of keeping the mind anchored in the sense that it is subtle, and its individual essence is continued pressure, similar to the humming of the bell. Initial application is the mind’s intervention at the moment of first emergence, like a bird spreading its wings to take flight, or a bee diving toward a lotus after previously catching its scent. The behavior of sustained application is calm, bordering on non-intervention by the mind, similar to a bird soaring with outstretched wings after taking flight, or the buzzing of a bee over the lotus once it has already dived onto it.
CHARACTERISTIC: Continued pressure on the object.
FUNCTION: Sustained application of associated mental phenomena to the object.
MANIFESTATION: It manifests as the anchoring of these phenomena upon the object.
PROXIMATE CAUSE: The object may be understood as its proximate cause.

3 \nDecision \n(adhimokkha)

DECISION (adhimokkha): The word adhimokkha literally means "the releasing of the mind onto the object." Therefore, it is translated as "decision" or "resolution." Because of its unshakable determination regarding the object, it is compared to a stone pillar.
CHARACTERISTIC: Conviction.
FUNCTION: Not groping [meaning the opposite of wandering in the dark "by touch"].
MANIFESTATION: Decisiveness.
PROXIMATE CAUSE: A thing to be convinced of.

ASSOCIATED WITH 78 or 110 TYPES OF CONSCIOUSNESS: \n\n Decision arises in all types of consciousness, except for the two sets of fivefold sensory consciousness and the consciousness accompanied by doubt.
4 \nEnergy \n(viriya)

ENERGY (viriya): Viriya is the state or action of one who is energetic. Just as new logs added to an old house prevent it from collapsing, or as strong reinforcements enable a king\'s army to defeat the enemy, so too does energy support and assist all associated states and not allow them to retreat.
CHARACTERISTIC: supporting, striving, and upholding.
FUNCTION: to support associated states.
MANIFESTATION: non-collapse.
PROXIMATE CAUSE: a sense of urgency (saṃvega) or any grounds for arousing energy, that is, whatever prompts energetic action.

ASSOCIATED WITH 73 TYPES OF CONSCIOUSNESS: \n\n Energy arises in all types of consciousness except for the five-door-adverting consciousness, the two sets of fivefold sense consciousnesses, the receiving consciousness, and the investigating consciousness (89 – 16 = 73).
5 \nRapture \n(pīti)

RAPTURE (pīti): It is of five kinds: minor rapture, momentary rapture, showering rapture, uplifting rapture, and pervading (thrilling) rapture. This fivefold rapture, when realized and cultivated, perfects the twofold serenity: serenity of mind and serenity of body. When serenity is realized and cultivated, it perfects the twofold happiness: bodily and mental. When happiness is realized and cultivated, it perfects the threefold concentration: momentary concentration, access concentration, and absorption concentration. In this context, rapture refers to pervading rapture, which is the root of absorption and arises through development in association with absorption.
CHARACTERISTIC: pīti has the characteristic of endearing (sampiyāyana).
FUNCTION: to refresh the body and mind, or its function is to pervade (to the point of thrilling).
MANIFESTATION: It is manifested as delight, elation [or enthusiasm].
PROXIMATE CAUSE: mentality-materiality (nāmarūpa) is its proximate cause.

ASSOCIATED WITH 35 or 51 TYPES OF CONSCIOUSNESS: \n\n Rapture arises in all types of consciousness except those accompanied by displeasure and equanimity, the two sets of fivefold consciousness, and the consciousness of the fourth jhāna.
6 \nDesire \n(chanda)

DESIRE (chanda): Chanda here signifies the desire to act (kattu-kāmatā), that is, to perform an action or achieve some result. This type of desire must be distinguished from desire in a reprehensible sense, that is, from lobha, greed, and rāga, passion. While these latter terms are always unwholesome, chanda is an ethically variable factor which, when conjoined with wholesome concomitants, can function as a moral desire to achieve a worthy goal. Desire should be regarded as the stretching forth of the mind’s hands towards the object.
CHARACTERISTIC: the desire to act.
FUNCTION: searching for an object.
MANIFESTATION: a need for the object.
PROXIMATE CAUSE: the object is its proximate cause.
ASSOCIATED WITH 69 or 101 TYPES OF CONSCIOUSNESS: \n\n Desire arises in all types of consciousness except for the rootless and the two types of consciousness accompanied by delusion (89 – 20 = 69).
